paragraphs.text: This pattern is evident with all employers, but let’s use startups as an example.
Create a side-project. Do something independently. Carve out a piece of your life, and mold it your way.

paragraphs.name: 188a
paragraphs.text: I think it’s fine to work a job. But you should make your own stuff. Don’t give it all at the office, and collapse on the couch sucked dry every night.

paragraphs.name: 4bcb
paragraphs.text: Increasingly, companies are demanding cult-like devotion. Do whatever it takes; sacrifice whatever you’ve got. It’s no longer enough to punch in, put in a solid day’s work, and go home. Now, you’re expected to be on Slack 24/7, use your social network to promote the company, recruit friends to the team, go to events in the evening, and use your personal equipment.
Parents don’t “fire” their kids.
paragraphs.name: c470
17ce
paragraphs.text: I don’t think you should give your best ideas to your employer.

paragraphs.name: cc31
paragraphs.text: But since starting my professional life 17 years ago, I’ve seen many friends who “gave it all” as employees, only to be spit out when they were no longer needed.

paragraphs.name: 188a
paragraphs.text: I think it’s fine to work a job. But you should make your own stuff. Don’t give it all at the office, and collapse on the couch sucked dry every night.
Create a side-project. Do something independently. Carve out a piece of your life, and mold it your way.

9527dcd00365.title: It seems to me that a company today is like a conveyor belt.

content.subtitle: They don’t actually care if you’re going to do your very best, amazing work, just as long as you don’t annoy anyone, stuff up really bad or…

paragraphs.name: b829
paragraphs.text: It seems to me that a company today is like a conveyor belt. The person hiring you isn’t always your manager or the owner. It’s someone in HR whose job it is to keep the conveyor belt full of workers. If someone leaves the conveyor belt (fired, retired, or hired by someone else) then they really just want someone who is ‘good enough’ to replace you.

paragraphs.text: A few years ago, I was interviewing for a UX Designer role. Now that I have children, one part of that interview boils my blood.

paragraphs.name: ee9b
paragraphs.text: Interviewer: “What do you like to do in your spare time?”

paragraphs.name: 88ba
paragraphs.text: Me: “Well, actually I enjoy designing stuff.”

paragraphs.text: Using sweeping statements like this (all is a fairly encompassing categorization) lead to trouble. I appreciate Justin’s point, but it was delivered…

paragraphs.name: 262f
paragraphs.text: Business is business. It’s primary purpose is to increase the bottom line–not enrich people’s lives, no matter what they say. If a business isn’t making money and growing, it has to change, or it dies. People come and go, it’s the nature of it. I think the point is to be aware of it and realize that there is no reason to invest your entire being into…
